author: Special Correspondent
text:
‘Changes in blacklisting procedures are being formulated’

Manohar Parrikar says that less the government is in any manufacturing sector, the faster it will progress.

Batting for greater de-regulation in the defence sector to promote manufacturing, Defence Minister Manohar Parrikar said on Saturday said instead the government should punish the wrong doers. However he cautioned that it had to be “unleashed” carefully.

“The defence sector is like a Doberman, when you unleash it, you have to be careful that it does not bite anyone. In defence exports, we have almost removed all restrictions and in 2016 there will be even easier ways of exporting even higher level material,” Mr. Parrikar said addressing a Business Summit.

To promote greater investment by foreign companies in the sector and bring in technologies, the government had raised the FDI in manufacturing to 49 per cent.

Mr. Parrikar said that it was “essential” and it could be higher on a “case to case basis.” “The process for that has been reduced to the ministerial level instead of the cabinet level which was much more difficult,” he said.

Mr. Parrikar had been pushing for changes in blacklisting procedures in case of wrong doing which has been adversely hurting the preparedness of the services. Instead the Ministry is contemplating heavy fines on those responsible. “I believe that the less the government is in any manufacturing sector, the faster it will progress,” he said.
title: Parrikar for punishing wrongdoers instead of more regulation
